arch:property.oc:show_val: Phase IV: Nabataean Grand Design: 1st c. BCE to CE 1st c. The remainder of the subterranean canalization is installed including the East Plaza Great Cistern. The East and South Perimeter Walls are installed and Rooms A and B and the Tabun Cave Room are built into the casemate of the East Perimeter Wall. The East Plaza and South Passageway are paved and the temple Forecourt is raised and laid with a small hexagonal pavement. Residential Quarter is built in the southwest corner of the precinct. Also at this time the Central Staircase of Phase II is blocked and the lateral East and West Staircases are constructed to access the Lower Temenos.
Main east-west wall south of the stairway (Locus 72) against the West Precinct Wall (Locus 38)

Locus 25 is the main east-west wall of the trench, abutting the West Precinct Wall (Locus 38), and extending the whole length of the trench. Its full extent has not been found, as it goes well beyond the confines of the trench, but as Dakhilallah expertly showed us, it appears to extend far to the west, and he further suggests that the small fallen column drums visible on the surface may once have rested on this wall. However, the wall is much more poorly preserved in the west of the trench, almost totally collapsed at the very edge of the trench. It is a much more sizeable wall than any others in the trench, besides of course the West Precinct Wall. It is very well constructed of substantial sandstone ashlars which are well cut but not dressed, and tightly laid with no evidence of mortar. The wall is two rows thick and five courses in height, though it should be mentioned that this wall was divided in the field into Locus 25 and Locus 82, which is the lower wider part of the wall; if this extension is included here, then the wall should be considered to have many more courses (though the exact number is obscured by the plaster on the south face of the wall). The north face of the wall is also partially covered in plaster, which even goes behind Locus 76, the north-south wall that abuts Locus 25. As this wall abuts the West Precinct Wall (Locus 38), and is abutted by Locus 76 as well as the stairway (Locus 72), and is further of a notably better and more sturdy construction than much of the rest of the trench, we propose that the construction of Locus 25 (and Locus 82 which it is combined with) is its own stage (Stage 2). Because of the impressive scale of this wall, suggesting an important role in the broader temple complex, we see this construction as being part of the Grand Design of the Great Temple during the first century BCE. The further articulation of this wall during the 2006 season would likely prove very helpful in our understanding of the relationship of the Great Temple to the broader area, especially the Baths to the west of the temple.
0.75 m north south -by- 8.70 m east west (exposed).
